title: In chapter 7 in determining home equity how does a reverse mortgage work? Just like a normal mortgage? Mom considering Bankruptc
question: Mom considering bankruptcy. How do we determine what if any equity she has since she has a reverse mortgage?
question_tags: Child support,Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy estate,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and student loans,Secured debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate
answers: You may be asking the wrong question. Equity is calculated like any other mortgage. However, what you want to know is "How will the Bankruptcy Trustee treat this house that is subject to a reverse mortgage?" You want to know if the Trustee is going to sell the house. The Trustee has the rights of hypothetical judgment lien creditor. Most reverse mortgages are set up in a way that a judgment lien can attach but not foreclose during the lifetime of the owner. You should consult an attorney to review your documents, but it is likely the Trustee would not attempt to sell the property even if your mother has more equity than the homestead exemption allows.

As a general rule, the equity is determined by deducting 8% (for sales costs if the property were to be sold), less the balance owing on the reverse mortgage if she as to see the property today. From that, she could deduct the homestead to which she s entitled, which is anywhere from $75,000 to $175,000, depending upon a number of factors. You and/or your mother should consult with an experienced bankruptcy attorney wth a free consultation to help ensure that she does not lose her home.

First, you have seen answer..same as any mortgage.

Second, NO attorney can advise you on what is protected called an exemption until they know all the facts INCLUDING whether the mom lived in that state for more than 2 years before filing!

Third, asking that question means you have not discussed with an experienced bankruptcy attorney which is really important and thus there are great ones here on Avvo and answering your questions too. Look , call and listen.

Finally, other issues and facts can gravely affect your case and thus will point those out for you next.

You need and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an
attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping
everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts. If you don't have any of the
exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523
(Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines , and
presumption of student loans. But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so
you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!
Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your
state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but
your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity
thereof!
Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your
options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you
have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply
with your attorney too.
But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a
relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that
relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the
bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so
meet with one no matter what.
Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one
as soon as you can.
You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of waiting versus filing now
and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.

As indicated by attorney Whitaker, the value of the home less the mortgage balance (not including any additional balance to lend) would determine her equity. She should be talking to an experienced bankruptcy attorney in her are to determine that calculation and to what exemptions she may be entitled.

I concur with atty Whitaker. Equity is the difference between what the property is worth less the balance owed on the mortgage. A debtor can exempt up to $175K depending on age, disabilities, how many live in the home. Talk to several BK lawyers in the area and hire one who: (1) Promptly returns your call; (2) Offers a free consultation by phone or in person; (3) Is willing to discuss fees; (4) Doesn't confuse you with legal mumbo-jumbo; (5) Has excellent client recommendations on Avvo or some other review system. Virtually all in pro per Chapter 13 cases are dismissed without lawyer assistance.

It's essentially the same calculation. Subtract the current payoff of the mortgage (not including available funds not yet paid out) from the current fair market value. If it's well under $200,000, it can likely be exempted.
